oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Postglacial Invasion Routes of Canadian Arctic Butterflies
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Freeman, T. N.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: theme:invasion pathway
invasion pathway
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>Several thousand specimens of arctic butterflies were accumulated in the Canadian Northern Insect Survey. When the distributions of the various species were recorded and plotted on a map, some evidence appeared that these insects entered Canada in postglacial times from the northwest, and from the south. There is also some evidence that a few may have come from the north. The most common invasion was from the northwest, and it appears that some, such as <jats:italic>Erebia youngi</jats:italic> Holl., probably entered Canada rather recently, as it is only known to occur in the Yukon. <jats:italic>Boloria pales</jats:italic> D. & S. occurs from the Yukon to within about 150 miles west of Hudson's Bay. <jats:italic>Colias boothii</jats:italic> Curt. occurs as far east as Southampton Island, and <jats:italic>Erebia rossii</jats:italic> Curt. is distributed to Baffin Island. Others such as <jats:italic>Boloria polaris</jats:italic> Bdv. have spread to northern Quebec and Labrador. Thus it appears that there are successive stages of distributional spread from the northwest.</jats:p>
